thread.title: Why protecting our big name brands like Gummee Glove is important
thread.title_full: Why protecting our big name brands like Gummee Glove is important

author: HannahFinch
title: Why protecting our big name brands like Gummee Glove is important
text:
Why protecting our big name brands like Gummee Glove is important By HannahFinch | Posted: April 26, 2017 0 COMMENTS SHARES Jodine Boothby the MD of Gummee Glove and Tom Moore, IP solicitor at Stephens Scown Why protecting our big name brands like Gummee Glove is important X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
A self-made entrepreneur who turned her teething toys concept into a £1 million-turnover company in less than five years is set to launch new 'world first' products - and its all down to the power of the brand. 
Cornish businesswoman Jodine Boothby, the inventor of the Gummee range of teething toys, said that protecting her intellectual property (IP) which has pioneered a never-been-seen before range has been vital to her Calstock-based business. 
Gummee has created the teething mitten with new products joining the range 
The mother-of-two launched the business with one product in 2012 after inventing the Gummee Glove teething mitten to help her son, Jimmy, when he was teething as a baby. 
The firm now sells a range of products worldwide both online and through a distribution network in 17 countries. 
Speaking on World IP Day , highlighting the importance of creating and protecting a recognisable brand, she said: "A recognisable brand, and what we stand for, how we represent ourselves and our products, can be what sets us apart. I realised within the first year of launching Gummee glove that we very much needed an over riding brand, to cover all products that we would bring to market. All we had at the time was the one product, and I realised that all though the product was doing very well, the name of that product would not be enough, to cover the other products. We needed a shorter, more distinct identity." 
Jodie said that protecting IP has given huge amounts of confidence when looking for distributors, starting accounts with large retailers and monitoring the competition." 
Gummee has just launched into the special needs market with a larger version of the Gummee glove, to help children with conditions that cause them to mouth their hands. 
She is also writing her first book, which will be launched in October. 
Jodie is among innovators behind some of the most recognisable brands in the Westcountry. 
Often, the biggest asset for names on the high street like Gummee Glove and St Austell Brewery in Cornwall and Luscombe Drinks in Devon is their IP - intellectual property. 
And protecting rights over their brand with trade marks, copyright and design rights means they can get the most of their brand in a global market place. 
Ben Travers, partner and head of intellectual property and IT at Stephens Scown said: "The success of the South West depends on entrepreneurs coming up with good ideas and having the courage to develop them. Intellectual property protection encourages innovation and helps businesses grow. Whether it is through trade mark registrations, copyright or registering design rights – there are several ways that businesses can protect their brands – which are often their most valuable assets." 
Stephens Scown has a growing IP and IT team and was ranked among the top 100 firms filing trade marks in the UK and EU, achieving the highest ranking for a firm based in Devon and Cornwall. 
It has helped a number of South West businesses protect their IP including St Austell Brewery, Lost Gardens of Heligan, Zero Carbon Future, Cornish Gems, Virtual Jet Centre and MC Kelly. 
Stephens Scown is a key partner in the Western Morning News' #BackTheSouthWest campaign. 
Mr Travers said: "The success of the region depends on entrepreneurs coming up with good ideas and having the courage to develop them. IP protection encourages innovation and helps businesses grow." 
He said that Brexit will mean that the UK will need to rethink its approach to this area, as currently many trade marks are registered across the EU. 
"Done well, this could lead to opportunities for UK firms, but if mis-handled it could hamper growth," he said. NEWS
